text:
New Yorkers throw away about 3
million tons of trash a year.

About a third of that is food scraps
and other organic materials.

Sending this to a landfill is expensive
and creates greenhouse gases.

So instead, the city wants
to turn it into

compost to enhance soil, and bio gas
to power homes and vehicles.

It's the largest residential
collection program in the country.

Below, sanitation workers toss
organics in the back of their truck.

On Staten Island scraps are delivered
to the city's facility in Fresh Kills

in the shadow of what used to be
one of the world's largest landfills.

Materials collected in other
boroughs will be

processed by private
facilities in the region.

Machines like The Tiger separate plastics
and non-compostable materials.

The compost made on Staten Island,
is sold to landscapers

or used in community gardens,
parks, schools and tree beds.

By the end of 2018,
the city says all New Yorkers

will have a way to recycle their
food scraps and other green waste.
